posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: We had some problems with the wiring of our encoders in our swerve modules. The bottoms of the encoders seem to be consistently touching the motor mounting plate. Has anyone else had this problem? It seems like something that should happen to more people and be more publicized.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: It would be very helpful to know what brand and model of swerve module and encoder you are using.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: I assumed it would at least be a semi-general problem. I don’t remember exactly which we have but I’m pretty sure it’s a variant of the sds mk3 or 4. We’re using CANcoders as the encoder.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: It’s unclear how mechanical interference is a wiring problem, unless you soldered wire to your CANcoders in such a way that it causes a problem.  If that’s what’s going on, the solutions would be to get the ones with pre-soldered wires, or to rework the solder and wiring to avoid the problem.  A picture would help…

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
1569.99 KB

See figure 3.2.4.2

I don’t think that’s the actual problem you’re having. What actual symptoms are present?

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: It’s also possible that it’s the wire that goes through the housing making contact with something. The problem is that something is touching both the encoder and the chassis and connecting them electronically.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Odd.  Only one encoder, or more than one?  How did you determine that something is connected to the chassis?  Do you see anything on the circuit board where the screws might be touching it?

I’d also look for something besides the screws – many teams use these and, as you pointed out, I’ve never heard of this being a problem.  This isn’t the same as saying you definitely haven’t run into a short of this type, but I wouldn’t be too quick to settle on this diagnosis.  It’s sometimes pretty hard to work out the cause of a short…

An easy thing to test is to see if the short goes away when the encoder isn’t in the case or not.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: The problem only occured when the encoder was in the housing and additionally, we covered the metal on the bottoms of the housings and that seemed to prevent it. The problem was on two out of the four modules.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
Ezra
posts.cooked: Referring back to previous comments, this seems like a problem that should be more common. Are we missing something basic or is it just a really rare occurrence?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Given that you have this on two encoders, it’s not rare for you.

I’ve never personally heard of this issue, and teams I’ve mentored have used at least four of these on robots for several years.  I’ve also not run across this as a CSA , nor do I recall seeing other reports here.  But, this does seem to be what you are seeing.

The PCB on units I just checked do have an insulating coating on them, so maybe yours don’t?  I really don’t have an explanation to offer.  I’m not sure what the normal clearance is, but I imagine it’s fairly close.  If you had screws that were taller than usual, that might be enough to cause trouble.  I could also see some assembly techniques leading to this type of problem, especially if the tops of the screws got chewed up when putting them in.  That’s all I’ve got, but close up photos of the PCB and the screws might help someone spot a problem.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: The middle plastic stud of the housing should also elevate the cancoder. If that’s been broken, it could allow the cancoder to sit lower than usual

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I took a few pics of in-the-box CANCoders last night in case they help.

It does look like there is “daylight” between the PCB and the screws.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: Could it be the screw that goes through the housing? Ours feel like they have no wiggle room distance-wise, but if one did extrude enough, it could touch the chassis.
